articles.summary: Monday 19 January Source : © European Union, 2026 - EP
articles.content:
Last-minute press briefing at 16:30

The Parliament’s Spokesperson and the Press Service will hold a press briefing on this week’s plenary session at 16:30. You can follow the last-minute briefing live.

Journalists wishing to take part and ask questions should please connect via Interactio.

Supporting innovative start-ups: the 28th regime

MEPs will discuss with Commissioner Michael McGrath their proposals for a “28th regime” for EU companies, in other words new harmonised rules tailored to small and medium-sized companies, startups and scaleups, designed to support innovation and competitiveness across national borders. They are expected to call for a new corporate form, the Unified European Company, that can be registered digitally within 48 hours in any EU country. Parliament will vote tomorrow at noon on a report intended to feed into a Commission proposal on the subject expected in the spring.

Martina VASS

(+32) 477 99 11 57

@EP_Legal

Tackling shortages in critical medicines

From around 18.30, MEPs and Commissioner Costas Kadis will be discussing a draft regulation that seeks to reduce the EU’s dependency on third countries for critical medicines (such as antibiotics, insulin, vaccines, and medicines for chronic diseases) and to boost the competitiveness of the pharmaceutical sector. MEPs will vote tomorrow on their position for talks with the member states.

Dana POPP

(+32) 470 95 17 07

@EP_PublicHealth

Motion of censure

Following the tabling of a motion of censure against the European Commission, there will be a plenary debate from around 20.00. A speaker supporting the motion will take the floor first, followed by Commissioner Maroš Šefčovič and one round of political group speakers. The vote, by roll call, will take place on Thursday. To be adopted, a motion must secure a two-thirds majority of the votes cast, representing a majority of the component members.

Andreas KLEINER

(+32) 498 98 33 22

Estefania NARRILLOS

(+32) 498 98 39 85

@EuroParlPress





In brief

Protecting workers. At around 19.00, MEPs and Commissioner Hadja Lahbib will discuss a draft report with recommendations to the Commission for a directive on securing a just green and digital transition. They will vote on the report tomorrow.

National and Regional Partnership Fund. Away from the hemicycle, three Commissioners (Fitto, Serafin and Hansen) will be attending a joint meeting of the Committees on Budgets, on Regional Development, and on Agriculture and Rural Development from 19.30. MEPs will be quizzing them on the Commission’s proposal for a European fund for economic, social and territorial cohesion, agriculture and rural, fisheries and maritime, prosperity and security (NRP Fund) under the EU’s 2028-2034 long-term budget.

Live coverage of the plenary session can be found on Parliament’s webstreaming site and on EbS+.

For detailed information on the session, please also see our newsletter.

Find more information regarding plenary.

articles.personality_title: EU Parliament advances new rules to support startups and secure medicine supply
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The European Parliament is meeting this week to discuss important plans aimed at helping small businesses, improving medicine availability, and protecting workers during the green and digital changes in Europe.

**What happened** – Members of the European Parliament (MEPs) talked with Commissioner Michael McGrath about creating a “28th regime.” This means new common rules for small and medium-sized companies, startups, and scaleups in the European Union (EU). They want a new company type called the Unified European Company, which could be registered online in any EU country within 48 hours. Tomorrow, MEPs will vote on a report that will help the European Commission make official proposals this spring.

Later, MEPs and Commissioner Costas Kadis discussed a plan to reduce the EU’s dependence on other countries for important medicines like antibiotics and insulin. This aims to make medicine production stronger inside the EU. A vote on this topic is also scheduled.

Around 7 pm, MEPs and Commissioner Hadja Lahbib reviewed ideas to protect workers as the EU moves toward greener and more digital jobs. They will vote on recommendations to guide the Commission’s future actions.

**Impact** – These discussions show the EU’s effort to make it easier for startups to grow across countries, improve medicine security so people can get the medicines they need, and help workers adjust fairly to new technologies and environmental goals. The new company form could speed up business registration, making it simpler to start and run companies in different EU nations.

**What's next step** – Tomorrow, MEPs will vote on reports about the new company rules, medicine supply, and worker protections. These votes will shape laws and policies the European Commission will work on in the coming months. The Commission plans to propose the new startup rules by spring.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The EU Parliament is moving forward with new plans to help startups grow faster, secure critical medicines, and protect workers during big changes in economy and technology.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le Parlement européen avance des règles pour soutenir les startups et sécuriser l'approvisionnement en médicaments
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Cette semaine, le Parlement européen se réunit pour discuter de projets importants visant à aider les petites entreprises, améliorer la disponibilité des médicaments et protéger les travailleurs face aux changements verts et numériques en Europe.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Les députés européens (DE) ont échangé avec le commissaire Michael McGrath sur la création d’un « 28e régime ». Il s’agit de nouvelles règles communes pour les petites et moyennes entreprises, startups et scaleups dans l’Union européenne (UE). Ils souhaitent créer une nouvelle forme d’entreprise appelée Société Européenne Unifiée, qui pourrait être enregistrée en ligne dans n’importe quel pays de l’UE en 48 heures. Demain, les députés voteront un rapport qui aidera la Commission européenne à faire des propositions officielles au printemps.

Plus tard, les députés et le commissaire Costas Kadis ont discuté d’un plan pour réduire la dépendance de l’UE aux pays tiers pour des médicaments essentiels comme les antibiotiques et l’insuline. L’objectif est de renforcer la production de médicaments en Europe. Un vote est également prévu sur ce sujet.

Vers 19 heures, les députés et la commissaire Hadja Lahbib ont examiné des idées pour protéger les travailleurs pendant la transition vers des emplois plus verts et numériques. Ils voteront des recommandations pour guider les futures actions de la Commission.

**Impact** – Ces discussions montrent l’effort de l’UE pour faciliter la croissance des startups à travers les pays, améliorer la sécurité des médicaments afin que les citoyens aient accès aux traitements nécessaires, et aider les travailleurs à s’adapter équitablement aux nouvelles technologies et objectifs environnementaux. La nouvelle forme d’entreprise pourrait accélérer l’enregistrement des sociétés, simplifiant ainsi la création et la gestion d’entreprises dans différents pays de l’UE.

**Prochaine étape** – Demain, les députés voteront sur les rapports concernant les nouvelles règles pour les entreprises, l’approvisionnement en médicaments et la protection des travailleurs. Ces votes orienteront les lois et politiques que la Commission européenne développera dans les prochains mois. La Commission prévoit de proposer les nouvelles règles pour startups au printemps.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Le Parlement européen fait avancer des plans pour aider les startups à se développer plus vite, sécuriser les médicaments essentiels et protéger les travailleurs face aux grands changements économiques et technologiques.
articles.personality_title_es: El Parlamento Europeo avanza nuevas reglas para apoyar startups y asegurar el suministro de medicinas
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Esta semana, el Parlamento Europeo se reúne para discutir planes importantes que buscan ayudar a las pequeñas empresas, mejorar la disponibilidad de medicinas y proteger a los trabajadores ante los cambios verdes y digitales en Europa.

**Qué pasó** – Los miembros del Parlamento Europeo (MEPs) hablaron con el Comisionado Michael McGrath sobre crear un “28º régimen”. Esto significa nuevas reglas comunes para pequeñas y medianas empresas, startups y scaleups en la Unión Europea (UE). Quieren una nueva forma de empresa llamada Compañía Europea Unificada, que podría registrarse en línea en cualquier país de la UE en 48 horas. Mañana, los MEPs votarán un informe que ayudará a la Comisión Europea a hacer propuestas oficiales en primavera.

Más tarde, los MEPs y el Comisionado Costas Kadis discutieron un plan para reducir la dependencia de la UE en otros países para medicinas importantes como antibióticos e insulina. Esto busca fortalecer la producción de medicinas dentro de la UE. También hay prevista una votación sobre este tema.

Alrededor de las 7 pm, los MEPs y la Comisionada Hadja Lahbib revisaron ideas para proteger a los trabajadores mientras la UE avanza hacia empleos más verdes y digitales. Votarán recomendaciones para guiar las futuras acciones de la Comisión.

**Impacto** – Estas discusiones muestran el esfuerzo de la UE para facilitar que las startups crezcan entre países, mejorar la seguridad en el suministro de medicinas para que las personas tengan acceso a sus tratamientos, y ayudar a los trabajadores a adaptarse justamente a nuevas tecnologías y objetivos ambientales. La nueva forma de empresa podría acelerar el registro de negocios, haciendo más fácil empezar y manejar empresas en diferentes países de la UE.

**Próximo paso** – Mañana, los MEPs votarán sobre los informes de las nuevas reglas para empresas, suministro de medicinas y protección de trabajadores. Estas votaciones influirán en las leyes y políticas que la Comisión Europea desarrollará en los próximos meses. La Comisión planea proponer las nuevas reglas para startups en primavera.

**Resumen en una frase** – El Parlamento Europeo avanza con planes para ayudar a las startups a crecer más rápido, asegurar medicinas críticas y proteger a los trabajadores durante grandes cambios en la economía y tecnología.

articles.title: Can ‘toxic masculinity’ be measured? Scientists try to quantify controversial term
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 19 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00144-4A study has outlined eight indicators of toxic masculinity in heterosexual men — and finds that ‘manliness’ is not necessarily a problematic aspect of masculinity.
articles.content:
Researchers have created a list of indicators of toxic masculinity.Credit: Getty

How rife is the problem of ‘toxic masculinity’ in Western societies? A research study run in New Zealand has found that only a small percentage of men surveyed fell into the worst category of hostile toxicity — and that a desire to feel ‘manly’ wasn’t necessarily indicative that a person held socially damaging views.

The term toxic masculinity was coined in the 1980s, and expresses the idea that some of the traits that many societies consider stereotypically ‘masculine’, such as dominance and aggression, can have damaging social impacts. Today, the phrase is often used to describe all manner of behaviours, from sexual violence to a disinclination to help with chores around the home.

The concept has proved helpful in many ways — highlighting how gender-based expectations can contribute to depression in men, for example, and encouraging men to see value in being open about their emotions. But it can also be problematic, researchers say. Casual use of the term might falsely imply, for example, that all societies think of manliness in the same way, that all masculine traits are negative, or that all men are toxic.

Researchers have delved into similar concepts, including hegemonic or patriarchal masculinity, which examines how a dominant, culturally idealized view of manhood upholds the patriarchy. But the term toxic masculinity hasn’t had as much academic attention. “Nobody measures it,” says psychology researcher Steven Sanders at Oregon State University in Corvallis. Some psychologists are now trying to pick apart and quantify its aspects.

In 2024, Sanders and his colleagues published a ‘toxic masculinity scale’, identifying 28 questions that assessed the degree of toxicity expressed by white male university students in the United States1. Psychology doctoral candidate Deborah Hill Cone at the University of Auckland in New Zealand and her colleagues have now added to this with a more all-encompassing view of toxicity and a larger, broader sample of men in a study published in Psychology of Men & Masculinities2.

‘Entitled rich tech bro’

Hill Cone and her colleagues identified eight indicators of toxic masculinity in heterosexual adult men in Western societies. These included prejudice against people’s sexual identities and ‘gender identity centrality’, which quantifies how important someone’s gender is to their sense of self.

The authors looked at both hostile sexism — for example, the belief that women seek to gain power by getting control over men — and benevolent sexism, such as the view that men ought to protect and cherish women. They also looked at whether men are opposed to domestic-violence prevention, and whether men think that societies generally contain some groups that are more deserving than others.

Why it’s essential to study sex and gender, even as tensions rise

The team dug into the results of the 2018–19 New Zealand Attitudes and Values Study, a broad survey with responses from nearly 50,000 people. More than 15,000 of the participants identified as heterosexual males and had answered relevant questions such as “being a woman/man is an important part of how I see myself” and “inferior groups should stay in their place”.

In a statistical analysis, the respondents fell into five groups. The good news is that only the smallest group (3.2% of the men) was characterized by the researchers as ‘hostile toxic’, whereas the largest group was ‘atoxic’ (35.4%). That’s not surprising, says Stevens. “On average, men aren’t monsters.” Between these groups, Hill Cone and her colleagues found two moderate groups split between those who were more- or less-tolerant of people from sexual and gender minorities (LGBTQ+) , and a ‘benevolent toxic’ group, whose members got relatively high scores in measures of sexism but not in hostility.

The odds of men in the sample having the hostile toxic profile were higher for those who were older, single, unemployed, religious or an ethnic minority, as well as those high on scales of political conservatism, economic deprivation or emotional dysregulation, or who had a low level of education.

“The entitled rich tech bro or frat boy didn’t really appear” in the hostile toxic group, says Hill Cone. Instead, the hostile toxic group was made up mainly of marginalized, disadvantaged men. “These are men without many resources, not men driving around in Lamborghinis.”
articles.reasoning: The article reports on a scientific study that quantifies toxic masculinity, providing nuanced insights that challenge stereotypes and highlight that only a small minority of men exhibit hostile toxic traits. This research promotes understanding of gender-related social issues and can help inform interventions to reduce harmful behaviors and improve social equality, benefiting society broadly.
articles.personality_title: New study measures toxic masculinity and finds only a small minority of men show harmful traits
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Toxic masculinity is a term used to describe certain harmful behaviors linked to traditional ideas of manliness, like aggression and dominance. Although the term is often discussed, it has been hard to measure or define clearly in science.

**What happened** – Researchers in New Zealand studied nearly 15,000 heterosexual men to identify signs of toxic masculinity. They created a list of eight specific indicators, such as negative views about gender and opposition to efforts against domestic violence. Their analysis showed that only 3.2% of men had strongly hostile toxic traits, while over a third showed no toxic traits at all.

**Impact** – This study challenges common stereotypes by showing that most men do not hold harmful views linked to toxic masculinity. It also reveals that men with hostile toxic traits tend to be from disadvantaged backgrounds, not wealthy or powerful groups. This new understanding can help target social programs more effectively.

**What's next step** – Researchers hope to use these findings to develop better ways to reduce toxic behaviors and support healthy expressions of masculinity. Future studies might explore how these traits change over time or in different cultures.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A detailed new study shows that toxic masculinity affects only a small portion of men and offers clearer ways to understand and address harmful gender attitudes.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une nouvelle étude mesure la masculinité toxique et révèle qu'une minorité d'hommes montre des traits nuisibles
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La masculinité toxique désigne certains comportements nuisibles liés aux idées traditionnelles de la virilité, comme l'agressivité et la domination. Bien que ce terme soit souvent utilisé, il est difficile à définir ou mesurer scientifiquement.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Des chercheurs en Nouvelle-Zélande ont étudié près de 15 000 hommes hétérosexuels pour identifier des signes de masculinité toxique. Ils ont créé une liste de huit indicateurs, comme des vues négatives sur le genre et l'opposition aux efforts contre la violence domestique. Leur analyse montre que seulement 3,2 % des hommes présentent des traits toxiques fortement hostiles, tandis que plus d'un tiers ne montrent aucun trait toxique.

**Impact** – Cette étude remet en question les stéréotypes courants en montrant que la plupart des hommes ne partagent pas les vues nuisibles liées à la masculinité toxique. Elle révèle aussi que les hommes avec ces traits hostiles sont souvent issus de milieux défavorisés, et non de groupes riches ou puissants. Cette nouvelle compréhension peut aider à mieux cibler les programmes sociaux.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs espèrent utiliser ces résultats pour développer de meilleures façons de réduire les comportements toxiques et encourager des expressions saines de la masculinité. Des études futures pourraient examiner comment ces traits évoluent dans le temps ou selon les cultures.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Une étude détaillée montre que la masculinité toxique touche une petite partie des hommes et offre des pistes plus claires pour comprendre et combattre ces attitudes nuisibles.
articles.personality_title_es: Nuevo estudio mide la masculinidad tóxica y encuentra que solo una minoría de hombres muestra rasgos dañinos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La masculinidad tóxica es un término que describe ciertos comportamientos dañinos vinculados a ideas tradicionales de masculinidad, como la agresión y el dominio. Aunque se habla mucho del tema, ha sido difícil medirlo o definirlo con claridad en la ciencia.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores en Nueva Zelanda estudiaron a casi 15,000 hombres heterosexuales para identificar señales de masculinidad tóxica. Crearon una lista de ocho indicadores específicos, como opiniones negativas sobre el género y la oposición a esfuerzos contra la violencia doméstica. Su análisis mostró que solo el 3.2% de los hombres tenían rasgos tóxicos hostiles fuertes, mientras que más de un tercio no mostraban ningún rasgo tóxico.

**Impacto** – Este estudio desafía los estereotipos comunes al mostrar que la mayoría de los hombres no tienen opiniones dañinas relacionadas con la masculinidad tóxica. También revela que los hombres con rasgos tóxicos hostiles suelen ser de entornos desfavorecidos, no de grupos ricos o poderosos. Esta nueva comprensión puede ayudar a dirigir mejor los programas sociales.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores esperan usar estos hallazgos para desarrollar mejores formas de reducir comportamientos tóxicos y apoyar expresiones saludables de la masculinidad. Estudios futuros podrían explorar cómo cambian estos rasgos con el tiempo o en diferentes culturas.

**Resumen en una frase** – Un estudio detallado muestra que la masculinidad tóxica afecta solo a una pequeña parte de los hombres y ofrece formas más claras de entender y abordar actitudes dañinas.
